descendants.content:
@Schepphimself @TheConversationUS I’m curious on your source for that stat. All the sources I can find don’t even have the US as worst in the OECD (Canada and Australia vie for that) with more than 10 other countries (mostly oil producing) even worse.

As a Canadian it’s frustrating that we’ve done so little up here (per capita emissions basically flat) while the US has dropped its emissions close to 25% since 2005.

descendants.content:
@TheConversationUS er. pretty much everyone knows it uses more *energy*. because of course it does.

the question more people care about is if it *costs more*, which is complicated because electricity prices often spike at the end of work days. in some places it *is* cheaper to run it all day, so your usage doesn't spike with everyone else's.

account.note:
Oddball, computer nerd, aspiring ecosystem co-creator, I've lead a strange and unlikely life. I dropped out of high school and was homeless for several years. During that time I learned Reiki, and how to operate and program Linux computers. I decided to get a job as a programmer, so I created a project and presented it at CodeCon 2004. That led to a career as a computer programmer. I'm now semi-retired and I've turned my attention to my other passion: gardening and ecology.

descendants.content:
@lauren @TheConversationUS my house is packed. 6 people with all their own schedules so it's rare that the house is empty of humans. Ditto regarding the pets; we have three cats and innumerable fish.
I think a better strategy is to focus on better insulation to reduce the demand for AC, contingent on local conditions.

account.note: IT guy turned SQL developer, always up to learn something new.

descendants.content:
@TheConversationUS Air conditioning is called “air conditioning”and not “cooling” because it is about both cooling and/or drying (humidity control), depending on your location. Between insulation, low-emissivity glass, and an overhang to shade the south-facing windows, my house only gets uncomfortably warm a few weeks of the year (used to be a few days, but climate change). Unfortunately, I live in a humid continental climate, and unless I want to be breathing black mold, I need humidity control in the summer*. It is currently provided with the old cool/dry heat pumps called “air conditioners” but will soon be replaced by a more efficient year-round heat pump system for heat/cool/dry air conditioning.

*I need it in the winter too, but that’s humidification to keep the doors and my skin from cracking
